content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several fragments of adipose tissue containing at least three distinct, highly cellular, basophilic structures consistent with lymph nodes. Two of the larger lymph nodes appear almost completely replaced by a dense, dark purple infiltrate, which is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. A smaller, less involved node is present on the far left. The overall impression is of multiple lymph nodes with significant tumor involvement.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the interface between the largest tumor-infiltrated lymph node (the one on the right) and the surrounding adipose tissue. This specific location is critical for assessing extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells beyond the lymph node capsule into the perinodal fat. ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor, and its presence or absence must be carefully evaluated and reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area because it is located at the interface between one of the large, tumor-infiltrated lymph nodes and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. This is a critical region to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of the tumor through the lymph node capsule into the surrounding fat. Determining the presence or absence of ENE is crucial for accurate staging and prognosis, as it signifies more aggressive disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each potential lymph node. This is the third major lymph node I am evaluating. I have zoomed into the periphery of this large, suspicious lymph node, specifically at the interface between the dense tumor infiltrate and the surrounding adipose tissue. The primary reason for examining this specific location is to assess for the presence of extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the lymph node capsule into the perinodal fat. ENE is a crucial prognostic factor and must be carefully evaluated and reported. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area, which is the large lymph node on the right, because it shows features highly suggestive of metastatic involvement. The goal is to confirm the presence of tumor at high magnification. Specifically, I need to examine the cytology of the infiltrating cells to verify they are malignant epithelial cells (carcinoma) and to observe their architectural arrangement (e.g., glandular formation). This confirmation is crucial for accurately staging the colorectal cancer, as the presence of lymph node metastasis (N stage) is a major prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area for two primary reasons. First, this is one of the large, suspicious lymph nodes that appears to be involved by tumor. Second, the selected area is at the interface between the infiltrated lymph node and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. This is the most critical location to assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor through the lymph node capsule into the adjacent fat. The presence of ENE is a significant adverse prognostic factor and is essential for accurate staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically evaluate every single lymph node identified in the specimen to determine the N-stage (nodal stage). I would zoom into this area because it represents a distinct, small lymph node located in the upper left quadrant, separate from the larger, more obviously involved nodes. It is crucial to examine all nodes, including the smaller and less suspicious ones, to accurately count the number of positive lymph nodes. This appears to be the first lymph node from the top-left that I am evaluating. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is located within one of the large, deeply basophilic nodules that are highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. The purpose of zooming in is to confirm the presence of malignant cells at high magnification, assess their cytological features (such as nuclear atypia, pleomorphism, and mitotic activity), and determine the type of tumor (e.g., adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated carcinoma) replacing the normal lymph node parenchyma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a clear demarcation between mature adipose tissue on the left and a dense sheet of malignant-appearing cells on the right. The border is irregular and infiltrative, not smooth or encapsulated. Tumor cells are seen directly invading the fat, both as individual cells and as small, irregular clusters. This morphology confirms the presence of metastatic carcinoma within the lymph node and, more importantly, provides definitive evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, the right side is composed of a dense, back-to-back proliferation of atypical glands and solid nests of malignant cells. The cells show hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, which is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. On the left, there is mature adipose tissue. The tumor is seen directly infiltrating into this adipose tissue without a discernible intervening lymph node capsule. My impression is a positive lymph node almost completely effaced by metastatic adenocarcinoma with clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 3. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see adipose tissue at the top and a dense sheet of malignant cells at the bottom. The malignant cells have dark, irregular nuclei and are arranged in poorly formed glandular structures and solid nests, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. Crucially, the border between the tumor and the adipose tissue is not smooth or encapsulated. Instead, I can clearly see irregular nests and single malignant cells infiltrating directly into the surrounding fat. This finding confirms the presence of metastatic carcinoma and provides definitive evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense, back-to-back proliferation of malignant glands, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are large and pleomorphic, with irregular, hyperchromatic to vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. They form fused, cribriform, and poorly-formed glandular structures, some of which contain necrotic debris. The surrounding stroma is infiltrated by these malignant cells. The black lines are likely artifacts. My impression is that this is definitively metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of the lymph node. The upper portion is densely packed with cells, representing a mixture of residual lymphocytes and infiltrating malignant cells. The malignant cells are arranged in irregular nests and poorly formed glands, characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The lower portion of the image shows mature adipose tissue. Crucially, at the interface, there are nests and single malignant cells infiltrating directly into the adipose tissue, away from the main tumor mass in the node. My impression is that this confirms the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma in this lymph node and, importantly, demonstrates clear evidence of extranodal extension (ENE).
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node with preserved lymphoid architecture, although it is heavily infiltrated by mature adipose tissue (the clear, round spaces). I can identify lymphoid follicles, some with reactive-appearing germinal centers. The cellular population consists mainly of small lymphocytes. I do not see any definitive nests, glands, or single files of atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific lymph node is that it is a reactive or involuted lymph node, and based on this view, it appears to be negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, the normal architecture of the lymph node is completely effaced. It is replaced by dense sheets of malignant cells. These cells are characterized by a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, hyperchromatic and irregular nuclei, and scant cytoplasm. The overall pattern is solid, lacking clear gland formation. This morphology is consistent with a metastatic, poorly differentiated carcinoma. The presence of these atypical epithelial cells confirms that this is a positive lymph node.
